seg.output: On the 7th of October, to my surprise, your letters arrived, most learned Heinrich, and I kissed them as if they were written by a brother. There, I could see the memory of an old friend had not yet been forgotten. Since you had saluted me first with your sweetest letters, and had offered an irreparable gift, and desired that the old friendship be restored from the heart, I thought it would be not only inhuman, but also unfair to deny such a just petitioner, so I should withdraw, before I forget you as an old friend and Leonhard Wirt, whom you mentioned in your letter, and with whom I had greatly benefited from the familiarity. Surely, if I had obeyed the advice of both, I would have sailed with better auspices. Finally, the Phrygians understand late. He, I say, was our common friend, so closely bound to me that I had him as a protection, I do not certainly know if he is alive. He stood out for his doctrine shortly after Doctor Cesar, as was a miracle.

seg.output: On the 5th of October, to my surprise, your letters arrived, most learned Henry, and I kissed them as if they were written by a brother. There, I was able to see the memory of an old friend not yet erased. So, since you had greeted me first with your sweetest letters and an inestimable gift, and had both of us desired to restore the old friendship with all our heart, I judged it not only inhuman, but also unfair to deny the just request, and I will withdraw myself before I forget you, an old friend, and Leonard Wirt, of whom you spoke in your letter, whom I had profited much from the familiarity with. Certainly, if I had obeyed the advice of both, I would have launched my letters with better auspices. At last, the Phrygians understand too late. This, I say, our common friend, so closely bound to me by relation, that I had him as my defense, I do not know if he is still alive. He was, in a short time, very much excellent in the doctrine of Doctor Cesario, as if it were a miracle. As for you, I had been informed of it more and more from my brother Jacob, traveler of Cologne, and from the report of the doctors, when you were still at Capelle. So that the friendship may remain intact, you commanded me to send you a greeting in return with my letters. I am certainly overwhelmed with shame to confess my ignorance, especially since from the beginning of my age I had already perceived you to be absolutely perfect, not only in letters, but also in moral integrity, besides that we had one thing in common, namely the same study, and we often frequented the library of preachers, and you read so often that it had done much harm to your eyes, as you had often complained to me, as if I were an intimate friend.

In particular, Chrysostom, of that golden mouth and of that flour and most learned in orthodox faith, in whom no one else had worked more. You had already given a sample of a great man by the testimony of everyone.

seg.output: On the 3rd of October, to my surprise, your letters arrived, most learned Henry, and I was able to kiss them as if they had been written by a brother. Thus, I was able to see that the memory of our old friendship had not yet been forgotten. Therefore, as you had greeted me before with your most sweet letters and with a gift that was not to be repented of, and as you desired both of us to restore our ancient friendship from the heart, I thought it certainly not only inhuman, but also unfair to deny such a just request, so I decided to withdraw before I stop remembering you, an old friend, together with Leonhard Wirt, whose name appeared in your letter, and with whom I had been greatly aided by their friendship. Indeed, if I had obeyed their advice, I would have left on better auspices. At last the Phrygians are becoming wise. That is, our common friend, who was so closely connected to me that I had him as a protector, is he alive? I do not know for sure. He quickly excelled in Doctor Cesario's doctrine, to the point of being a miracle. I had heard from time to time about you, both from my brother Jacob, the Cologne traveler, and from the account of the doctors, when you were still at Capelle. As for that amity to remain unharmed, you command me in return to greet you in my letters. I blush from shame to declare my ignorance, especially since from the beginning of my age I have known you to be completely perfect not only in letters, but also in moral integrity, besides the fact that we were one in the borders, namely that we had a common study, that we often frequented the bookseller's of the preachers and that you were so frequent in your reading that you had caused much damage to your eyes, as you often complained to me, like an intimate. Above all, you had worked very hard on Chrysostom, with his golden mouth and his flour, and especially with his very learned orthodoxy, which no one else had done as much. It is easily testified that you had already then presented a specimen of a great man. Now the world enjoys the fruits of such greatness. You not only leave behind a famous name to posterity, but also your illustrious country, without dispute, of the pious.

seg.output: On the third of October, much to my surprise, your letters arrived, most learned Henry, and I kissed them as if they were written by a brother. There, I was able to see the memory of an old friend, not yet erased. So, since you had first greeted me with your sweetest letters and an unrepayable gift, and had restored our old friendship from the heart, I thought it would be both inhuman and unjust to deny your just request, so I will withdraw myself before I cease to remember you as an old friend and Leonhard Wirt, whom you mentioned in your letter, with whom I had enjoyed much of the friendship. Indeed, if I had obeyed the advice of both, I would have sailed with better auspices. The Phrygians understand late. I mean, our common friend who was so tied to me by relationship that I had him for my support, I do not know if he is alive or not. He was quickly distinguished by Doctor Cesario for his doctrine, as a miracle. But about you, I had become more and more informed, both by my brother Jacob, who was travelling to Cologne, and by the reports of the doctors, when you were still in Capelle. But in order that our friendship remains unharmed, you command me to greet you in return with my letters. With certain shame I confess my ignorance, especially since I have always had you, from the beginning of your age, perfectly seen not only in letters but also in the integrity of your morals, besides the fact that we were dealing with one common thing, namely the study, we often visited the bookshop of the preachers and you had so frequent readings that you had caused much harm to your eyes, as you often complained to me, as to an intimate one. Above all, Chrysostom, to that golden mouth and to this flour, and especially to the most learned faith orthodoxy, to whom no one worked more than you. You had easily given, according to the testimony of all, a specimen of a great man. Now the world enjoys the fruit of such a genius. Not only do you leave your famous name to posterity, to your illustrious homeland, but even beyond controversy, to the pious. Your daily works are patronized by you, not to mention that the Frenchman Verden praised you to the world. Therefore, in order that our friendship remains closer on both sides, I will not be reluctant to write to you - for I want you to recognize the candor of my soul, not the promise of my writings - and I would have written to you a more extended letter, if I had been narrowed down by the burden of things, due to the vintage.

Not only do you leave a famous name to posterity, but also your illustrious homeland without controversy of the pious.

Thus, I could see that the memory of our old friendship had not been forgotten. Therefore, since you had greeted me first with your sweetest letters and an unrepayable gift, and we both wished to restore our old friendship from the heart, I thought it would not only be inhuman but also unfair to deny such a just request, so I decided to write to you before I forget you, the old friend, and Leonhard Wirt, whom you mentioned in your letter, with whom I had been very close. As for you, I had heard of you from my brother Jacob, who was a traveller from Cologne, and from the reports of the doctors, when you were still studying in Capelle. In order that our friendship remain unharmed, you ask me to greet you in return with my letter. I blush with shame to reveal my ignorance, especially since, since early childhood, I had already perceived you to be not only perfectly versed in letters, but also of the highest integrity of morals, apart from the fact that we shared the same studies, we often visited the library of the preachers and you read so much that your eyes suffered much damage, as you complained to me like an intimate. Everyone had easily noticed the example of the great man that you had already shown. Now the world enjoys the fruit of such a genius. Your daily studies are sponsored, not to mention that the Frenchman Werdense praised you to the world. Therefore, in order for our friendship to remain closer, I would not hesitate to write to you at length, so as not to promise a written word, but to recognize the candour of the soul in me - if I were not constrained by the burden of the harvest.

seg.output: On the fifth of October, to my great surprise, letters arrived from you, most learned Heinrich, and I was able to kiss them as if they were written by a brother. Thus, I was able to see that the memory of an old friend had not yet been erased. So, since you had greeted me first with your most sweet letters and you wished for the old friendship to be renewed from the heart, I thought it not only inhuman but also unfair to deny such a just request and I shall not hide away, before I forget you, an old friend and Leonhard Wirt, of whom you mentioned in your letter, with whom I had much benefit from their acquaintance. Certainly, if I had obeyed the advice of both, I would have sailed with better letters as beginnings. Finally, the Phrygians understand late. I mean, our common friend, so closely connected to me that I had him as my defense, is he still alive? I do not know for certain. He was remarkable in his skill through Doctor Cesario, as if it were a miracle. As for you, I had heard about you from my brother Jacob, the traveller from Cologne, and from the reports of the learned, when you were still at Capelle. So that the friendship may remain unharmed, you command me to greet you in return with letters. I blush in shame to reveal my ignorance, especially since from my early age I had already seen you as a man of perfect letters and integrity, apart from the fact that we were together in a border, that is, our common study, and we often visited the library of the preachers and you read so much that it caused much harm to your eyes, as you had often complained to me, your intimate friend. Above all, you had labored in Chrysostom, that golden-mouthed one and most learned in the orthodox faith, as it was easy to show by the testimony of all. Your daily writings are praised by everyone, not to mention that the Frenchman Werdensis had recommended you to the world. So, that our friendship may remain closer on both sides, I would write to you a more extended letter, were I not so busy with the harvest. However, my state and condition are known by the messenger. Farewell in the Lord. Your Sebastian Locher. To the man of seen learning, Master Heinrich Bullinger, an old friend of his.
